title: Body cam footage shows moments after Labrador stepped on a gun and shot woman
text:
Police body cam footage has captured the moments after a woman was shot in the leg by a Labrador inside of a pick-up truck.

The dramatic incident occurred in Enid, northern Oklahoma last Thursday after the startled pooch jumped onto the center console and set off a loaded gun.

Cops quickly arrived on the scene to find 44-year-old Tina Springer writhing in agony.

Springer was a passenger in the vehicle, and the footage - released on Tuesday - shows her sliding out of the truck's right-hand side as she holds her left thigh.

The Labrador, meanwhile, remains perched on the center console, seemingly oblivious to the drama she has inflicted.

Officers found three shell casings inside the truck, according to Oklahoma News 4.

The seven-month old pup, named Molly, belongs to Brent Parks, 79, who was driving the pick-up truck at the time of the shooting.

Springer acts as Parks' carer and the pair were running errands together before the incident.

The Enid local was rushed to hospital to be treated for her gunshot wounds, and is due to be released on Tuesday evening.

Meanwhile, Mr Parks appears to be taking the accident in good humor.

On Tuesday, the elderly man paraded his pup around his yard for the Oklahoma News 4 cameras, saying: 'There's the killer dog! Well, she didn't kill her...'

His upbeat demeanor was a far cry from the 911 call her made following the shooting last Thursday.

Springer was a passenger in the vehicle, and the bodycam footage - released on Tuesday - shows her sliding out of the truck's right-hand door as she holds her left thigh

The seven-month old pup, named Molly, belongs to Brent Parks, 79, who was driving the pick-up truck at the time of the shooting

In audio from the 911 call, Parks tells the dispatcher everything that happened.

'Well a gun went off. Got her in the leg. She didn't do it herself. I had a dog in here and he stepped on the gun,' Parks says.

'The dog shot her?' the dispatcher asked. Parks answered: 'Yes, she stepped on it and it went off. But anyway, can you get an ambulance out here.'

Meanwhile, Springer is heard in the background saying, 'I don't feel good' and 'tell my kids I love them'.

'She's bleeding pretty bad,' Parks is heard saying.

'She's alert but she's losing blood bad. I'm trying to find something to wrap around her leg but she's a screaming and all this sh*t,' a frustrated Parks is heard saying.

The dispatcher then asks Parks if he has a clean dry cloth. 'If I had a clean dry cloth it would've already been on her ma'am,' Parks retorts.

He then says he can use his belt and the dispatcher instructs him to make a tourniquet with the belt.

Police later determined that the cloth from the seat covers may have gotten into the trigger well of the gun, making it discharge.

Officers say Parks told them the gun isn't usually loaded.
description: The dramatic incident occurred in Enid, northern Oklahoma last Thursday after the startled pooch jumped onto the center console and set of the loaded weapon.
